title: Between 10 July and 31 December 2020, will a firm or paid backup driver operating a self-driving vehicle face criminal charges in relation to an accident involving a self-driving vehicle in the U.S.?
preds: Crowd forecast 95% no? I pity the fools. Unless I am he.

Timing. I think the behaviour of the crowd score on this question warrants a slight modification of the GJOpen forecasting system as I suggest here:
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1202429

I've burned up lots of Brier Score lately, but what the heck. Again, the criminal charges filing is literally here: 
https://www.maricopacountyattorney.org/DocumentCenter/View/1724/Rafael-Vasquez-GJ-Indictment
Paid backup driver? Check.
Self-driving vehicle in the US? Check.
Clarification that it doesn't matter that it was a grand jury indictment rather than filed by a prosecutor? Check.
Between 10 July and 31 December 2020? Check. The only sticking point is that the crowd still has it at 93% no. I am almost never right going against a crowd that's that confident. At this point it's worth burning up more Brier Score just to learn why it's not yes. Good luck, all.

Thanks @SE_Meyer. Hat-tip for others working the clarifications too... Interesting reading here....
https://www.irva.org/library/stargate-guide

On the 30 November 2020 note clarifying "A defendant will 'face criminal charges' upon being charged".
I still think this applies to the ongoing proceedings in the Maricopa County case. @Tolga @Balzac ?
[EDIT: deleted, as it's redundant to what people have posted below]

@Tolga @Balzac
I wonder if you noticed there's a clarification note of 12 November now concerning the question we've discussed: what concisely means "face criminal charges". As I read it, I feel it confirms our latest finding (the criminal charges were charged/filed this summer...), am I correct?
Taking a calculated risk awaiting official clarification on https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-54175359

https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-54175359
She was charged.
Why are forecasters still forecasting No? I am confused.
Small potential for an individual, slightly larger for a firm given their exposure to the larger quantity of cars. The rest is just the math.
Increasing due to charges brought against a driver in UK

Updating my original forecast for the evolved scenario.  I gave 2% chance of not mature companies acting like rogues and divided it by 2 due to Covid reducing traffic. The forecast was in end of July. There were 5 months left in the forecast.
Now there are 2, so the probability should get reduced to 0.5%, moving to 0% given no new developments.  That would have been my update but for: 
https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-54175359 "Ms Vasquez was charged on 27 August, and made her first appearance in court on 15 September. The trial is now set for February next year." So it seems charges were bought on 27 August, 1m after my original forecast. But the first trial will take place in Feb 2020. So my reading means my forecast failed. I put this in the "spectacularly wrong" category. There may be an argument that the absence of a conviction means I'm right. But 1) the phrasing of the question clearly states "charges" not "conviction"; and b) even if true, so what? My forecast was spectacularly wrong regardless of whether it shows in my Brier. It turns out Uber has been cleared of any criminal responsibility for this incident but has been strongly criticised. 
My only excuse was it was my first venture into these types of forecasts. But more interesting than pure ego protecting (aka excuses) is where I went wrong. It's been a while since I went wrong by this much, but one learns far more by going wrong than by being right. My forecast about the firm was actually pretty much bang on, so my error was my backup driver forecast.  This was based on the following:
"There cannot be criminal charges if there is no mens rea. If a backup driver was not fully concentrating, it's hard to see how any reasonable person could have been concentrating 100% of the time so to prove civil law negligence is going to be difficult. To prove criminal negligence will be impossible. And with no reasonable prospect of a successful prosecution, there will be no convictions. Instead it will just be called an accident in the normal way." This analysis was absolutely correct with respect to a normal person driving. But the Uber incident involved a backup driver who "spent 34% of the time looking at her cell phone while streaming a TV show".  That is a stunningly negligent act that seems to me to fairly clearly meet a criminal negligence threshold.  My error was to foresee how idiotic some of these paid backup drivers would be! This is an experimental technology. They knew the car would likely go wrong at some point. And yet this lady spend almost 1/3 of her time watching a TV show! I cannot fathom the stupidity of that person. So it seems that I radically overestimated the training and sensibility of the paid backup drivers. A genuine back-up driver watching the road but getting bored and as a result being slow to react would be safe under my above logic. But this level of idiocy permitted by Uber to get behind the wheel I did not foresee. Is this a genuine mistake, or just hindsight? The problem with the hindsight excuse is it doesn't actually surprise me human nature is that way particularly given the levels of boredom one must get as a backup driver. Absence of surprise implies benefit of hindsight cannot entirely explain this error.  But that's not the only mistake I made. With about 6 months of forecasting to go, it would make sense to check if there were any incidents that might yield criminal charges, particularly given it takes time for processes to move so if there wasn't anything at that moment, half the remaining time would likely elapse before any new cases could result in any criminal charges. Looking at the BBC article reveals an article on the same incident (https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-47468391) dated March 2019. This article, over a year before my forecast, clearly said:
"Dash-cam footage released by police after the incident appeared to show the vehicle's back-up driver, Rafaela Vasquez, taking her eyes off the road moments before the crash. Further records from the streaming service Hulu suggested that Ms Vasquez had been streaming the TV show, The Voice, on a phone at the time of the crash." Had I properly read this, I would have seen a serious risk of criminal charges. But I didn't see it. My conclusion is I botched my research and should have looked at the most recent incidents before making the forecast. There can be no "hindsight" argument here. This is something I should have done. Further, this mistake does not impact solely my backup driver forecast. It also hits my firm forecast because I should have looked at this before making that forecast also. After all, the article in March before my forecast stated "Uber will not face criminal charges, after a decision last year that there was "no basis for criminal liability" for the corporation." That was an important miss. So even my correct 
firm forecast was to some extent botched. Final conclusions: 
1) When people are bored, people can be very stupid. 
2) Always do a quick search for recent cases for questions like this.
3) 90% of my forecast was still correct but the forecast failed due to the botched 10%. So I'm not that far aware from being good at these questions but my backtesting suggests I'm not there yet. Further, looking at the below, only one person mentioned the significance of Rafaela Vasquez (nicely done @JPJCB).

I'm opening the possibility slightly due to news that a company is releasing fully autonomous vehicles in Arizona. However, I think that 3 months is not enough time for it to be likely for a situation to develop and charges to be brought. 
https://oilprice.com/Energy/Energy-General/The-Worlds-First-Fully-Driverless-Vehicle-Ready-To-Hit-The-Roads.html I still maintain my previous reasoning that a paid backup driver will be like an airline pilot and will have a good understanding of what the limits of the artificial intelligence are and when to intervene and take over. I think professional backup drivers are a lot different from someone simply owning a car like a Tesla who may not know what the limits of the vehicle are and may use the autopilot improperly.
Because the laws and responsibility aren’t clear enough yet for this to happen.

I've asked for clarification with the following question: Does "face criminal charges" refer to the announcement of "criminal charges" by prosecutors [1] or the begin of judicial proceedings [2]? [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1150686 [2] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1134988 Answer: "To "face criminal charges" would be to have criminal charges brought against a defendant relevant to this question. As there remains more than one possible answer for the question (either "Yes, a paid backup driver" and "Yes, both"), the question will remain open." @SE_Meyer @cdob63 @Tolga @Balzac

Looks to me like this has already happened, at least as to charges against a driver:
https://www.npr.org/2020/09/16/913530100/backup-driver-of-autonomous-uber-suv-charged-with-negligent-homicide-in-arizona
The accident was in 2018, but the charge was apparently just laid, and the Q is about when the charges are filed.  Any reason I'm wrong about this, as I am about most things?  Question probably needs to be kept open in case somebody later charges a firm for this or a different incident.

The Uber driver in Arizona has been charged with a class 4 felony. Felony is a 'serious crime' (vs. misdemeanor), so presumably that meets the test of 'criminal charges'. It's really ambiguous though what 'face criminal charges' means. Does that mean 'be convicted of' or 'charged with'? I'd say that 'face criminal charges' covers the broader 'charged with'. But since there is a bit of ambiguity, it would be nice to get a clarification. The other fatal accidents all involved the driver who was ostensibly 'in control of the vehicle' so I don't know how the firm could be charged.
Testing is still going on, but everything I checked included a supervising driver in the car so again, it's really unlikely the firm could be charged: https://www.nhtsa.gov/automated-vehicles-safety/av-test-initiative-tracking-tool

I have noticed that forecasters have tipped towards some "YES" answer lately. As I read the allegations, she will "face charges" in relation to the deadly accident, which would close the question YES.
However, it remains unclear to me, whether the alleged "negligent homicide", as reported by the dw source, will fulfill the condition of a "criminal charge" in the US, as also demanded by the question.
Is "negligent homicide" really a criminal charge, can anyone get us more clarity? Thanks. EDIT: in German law at least, a distinction is being made between "grobe Fahrlässigkeit" (culpable negligence/wanton negligence/gross negligence), which is a criminal charge in most cases, and "Fahrlässigkeit" (negligence), which is not a criminal charge in most cases. I bet it depends in the Arizona case on whether the drivers negligence was "culpable" or not for the question to resolve "YES". To be more concise: "Vasquez was accused of being distracted on her phone at the time of the accident but she denied using the device while talking to investigators."
My understanding is that using her phone at the time of the accident (which will be a matter of proof) would make her negligence "culpable", but the defendant denies having done so. It will, however, be more interesting to me whether UBER's "inadequate safety procedures" and "the deactivation of Uber's automatic emergency braking system" will lead to a criminal charge that UBER will ultimately face. Finally, it was UBER's fault that the cyclist or "object" was detected 5.6 seconds prior to the impact, but the system failed to categorize the "object" correctly or convert the detection into any action to safeguard the cyclist. Initially, I did not intend to answer the question at all, since I'm not intending to put much time into legal detail research; on the other hand, the dw article states: "In March 2019, prosecutors had declined to file criminal charges against Uber. Vasquez is set to face trial in February 2021." So technically, the question will probably resolve "NO" due to the fact that any (criminal or not) charge that will happen will lie outside of the time frame the question sets, and it would depend on criminal charges in a different case than the Vasquez case.

I mjst be the last to know.
https://thehill.com/homenews/state-watch/516640-back-up-uber-driver-charged-in-fatal-crash-of-autonomous-car

Small number of driverless vehicles makes this unlikely. Backup driver would only be held responsible if they were negligent.  Firm would be held accountable if it could be shown accident happened due to a flaw in the technology but this takes time to establish

This question is completely obscured by the as yet undetermined fate of Rafaela Vasquez, the backup driver of the Uber car responsible for a pedestrian death in 2018. I judge that ignoring this case, the chances of an accident for which criminal charges is then brought is extremely low - i.e. around 5%. However, it is possible that Vasquez faces charges for the 2018 incident (the Arizona prosecutor has ruled out charging Uber) and frustratingly, there's very little public information to determine this likelihood. Given the somewhat short time window, plus the indeterminacy of the outcome, I judge it overall less than likely she will be charged. But there is significant uncertainty.
I don’t see any fatalities or injuries involving a self driving car between those dates.

There cannot be criminal charges if there is no mens rea. If a backup driver was not fully concentrating,  it's hard to see how any reasonable person could have been concentrating 100% of the time so to prove civil law negligence is going to be difficult.  To prove criminal negligence will be impossible.  And with no reasonable prospect of a successful prosecution,  there will be no convictions. Instead it will just be called an accident in the normal way.  Same is true for firms except for the small risk they rush a prototype onto the roads without taking necessary safety precautions. Self driving car companies are not mature companies so there is a small chance they could act like rogues, say 2%. Covid 19 means fewer people in the road so halving probability of accident during this time to 1%.
Low risk due to COVID-19 pandemic related traffic reduction
Not likely this year, but more likely next year.

Weight of numbers of car accidents. I'm not from U. S.   but... I believe any accident where there is a medical bill someine is getting sued. The volume of accidents will mean it's likely a back up driver or company will be involved

The government are keen for the technology to work. They will not be quick to allow this situation. A firm is a legal individual as an entity. An individual will not be charged as the technology is new.

Coronavirus will dominate this year meaning less expansion of tech. There also won't be a public/political will to make an example of tech vehicles in this period as Covid and the economy are the main focus.

If it hasn't happened yet, I doubt it will on this timeline.
https://www.nbcnews.com/tech/tech-news/self-driving-uber-car-hit-killed-woman-did-not-recognize-n1079281

The technology is new and still in testing phase. The government will not want to discourage the development of the technology by exposing people or companies to criminal charges. A criminal charge if brought would only be if there was a major accident and to satisfy public opinion.  The likely hood of a driver being charged is 1% or less as the drug and alcohol testing for any back up driver will be extensive. Criminal charges in my opinion could only be brought under cases where the back up driver would be under the influence, had intent or was negligent to the extreme.

My understanding is that self-driving vehicles still require humans to take over when necessary, and that most accidents involving self-driving vehicles can be attributed to 1. the driver of the other vehicle or 2. human negligence. Given this information, it seems more likely that a backup driver would face criminal charges than a firm. This is what happened with the Uber crash and several Tesla crashes (see links in question). However, the number of self-driving cars is much higher than the number of self-driving cars with a paid backup driver. Also based on these articles, it takes 6 months to over 2 years before charges are pressed. This means that if a firm or driver were to be charged, it would likely be from an accident that has already occurred. There are 4 potential charges that could be brought by the end of 2020 (that I'm aware of), 1 against a driver and 3 against Tesla. Although there are more charges against Tesla, I believe it will be harder to fault Tesla since drivers are still responsible while the car is on autopilot. Potential charges:
http://www.automotive.news.online-listing.com/2020/03/14/2-years-after-uber-crash-charges-remain-possible-3/
https://arstechnica.com/cars/2020/02/data-shows-tesla-owner-experienced-same-glitch-days-before-deadly-2018-crash/
https://www.theverge.com/2019/8/1/20750715/tesla-autopilot-crash-lawsuit-wrongful-death
https://www.forbes.com/sites/lanceeliot/2020/05/16/lawsuit-against-tesla-for-autopilot-engaged-pedestrian-death-could-disrupt-full-self-driving-progress/#5baf6bae71f4
Firm is more lucrative target but overall chance is small
Liability rests with the driver. It would be difficult to probe the company was at fault of the driver were negligent
Nascent technology, Covid-19, and money behind said tech will prevent this scenario from occurring.
This technology is almost new I think the answer is NO

Society already relies on car insurance to cover damages caused by a vehicle driven by another human being. This coverage varies from country to country but that does not mean it changes just because there is no active driver or even back up driver. Currently, a human causing an accident that results in property damage is not charged criminally. However, if a human driver accidentally kills another human being with a vehicle then yes they can be criminally charged with manslaughter. I would think that this doesn’t change in driverless or backup driven vehicles. The criminal liability should be handled by the firm, if the vehicle is operated by their employee. If the person acting as a backup driver operates independently then they (or their LLC) would be liable for the lawsuits and criminal penalties for the death of another human being.

Unlikely but possible. Fewer self-driving cars are on the road because of the pandemic. However, pedestrians and bicyclists have been in the streets more than previously and may test self-driving software to its limit.

I really want to dissent... but I can't. I don't know anyone that has left the house in three months. In general, I can presume there is at least a mild dip in people on the road these days. Coupled with the short timeline, even if there was an egregious accident, I feel the resulting investigation and palm greasing would consume several months. If something happened today, maybe we'd see criminal charges before December. Other than that, any damage to personal property is undoubtedly insured against and would likely be settled outside court unless an enterprising DA got in the mix.

*Rationale remains the same as that for the related question:  Right now, it appears highly unlikely that "criminal charges" will be brought against a company or a person, for an "accident" (I have issue with this language as it is vague; isn't it for the court to determine whether something was an 'accident,' in this instance?) involving an autonomous vehicle.
court action during the pandemic is slow, and the reduced number of cars on the road ,makes this unlikely

There isn't enough self-driving cars in circulation for the likelihood of a severe accident to be high (though San Francisco does have a high death rate for traffic accidents ref: n 2019, 42 people were killed in traffic violence in San Francisco). Self-driving cars have also shown to contribute to a reduction in accidents: http://www.traffictechnologytoday.com/news.php?NewsID=62827
In addition the legal liability remains unclear though the legislation is leaning towards holding the backup drive responsible, although Volvo have said they will be responsible for any accidents due to system faults (https://www.media.volvocars.com/global/en-gb/media/pressreleases/167975/us-urged-to-establish-nationwide-federal-guidelines-for-autonomous-driving)
So a small chance of accident and in the case of an accident more likely to be the responsibility of the backup driver.
I think it will happen but not before December 31
Criminal charges are very unlikely.  There may be a civil suit seeking damages.

The likelihood of all of this happening eventually is 100%, but Coronavirus is reducing demand for, and the speed of, a driverless rollout.   I'd look for it in the 3- to 5- year timeframe, not before December.
Going to 95 from 90 for "No" to correct for the very confident crowd
Guess I follow the crowd on this one.

Too soon. A criminal negligence conviction is difficult to achieve on a good day for an active driver. It will be much more difficult to secure such a conviction with respect to a backup driver, so I seriously doubt any charging decisions would be made this year on such a case. Experience will first need to be derived from civil litigation involving self-driving vehicle before criminal cases begin to pop up. This is still more than a year away, in my opinion.

The timeframe is short. The quantity of self driving vehicles owned and operated by firms is limited, criminal charges are for recklessness and hit and run which are not prevalent with self driving cars.  I guess the paid backup driver could be asleep or drunk after a pedestrian fatality but that is super slim.  Autopilot does a hit and run on its way to McD?

A Tesla driver using autopilot was just charged criminally, but what firm is paying back up drivers? I see a lot of problems here because people expect the software to do too much and don't understand the proper limitations. But I just don't think very much of this is going on yet. https://jonathanturley.org/2020/07/05/driver-using-autopilot-technology-criminally-charged-after-collision/
I'll follow @K-M-G and go straight to the cellar. TIme frame is too short.
